title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SACRAMENTO – In a league of giants, one man stood tallest. Mitch Richmond did not just beat the Portland Trail Blazers on this night in 1998; he authored a masterpiece of individual brilliance, carrying the Sacramento Kings to a gritty 94-87 victory with a performance for the ages.

From the opening tip, Richmond was uncontainable. He sliced through the Blazers’ defense, his mid-range jumper a metronome of precision. He attacked the rim with force and stepped back behind the arc with cold-blooded confidence. While the Kings’ offense often stagnated, Richmond was the relentless, unstoppable constant. Every time Portland threatened to build momentum, the All-Star guard had an answer, a basket, a play to silence the run and steady his team.

His final line was staggering: a career-high and franchise-record 47 points. He did it efficiently, shooting over 50% from the field while also chipping in 5 rebounds and 5 assists, a complete offensive tour de force. Isaiah Rider’s 20 points for Portland were a mere whisper against Richmond’s roar.

The final score belies the singular nature of the contest. This was not a tale of two teams, but of one man’s will imposed upon a game. The Kings provided just enough support—a key bucket from Corliss Williamson, a defensive stop from Olden Polynice—to build a scaffold, but the entire structure was built upon Richmond’s historic output. In an era defined by defensive battles, Mitch Richmond transcended the game itself, delivering a 47-point declaration that will forever be etched in the Sacramento record books.
